transcript: A few years ago, I broke into my own house. I had just driven home. It was around midnight in the dead of Montreal winter. I'd been visiting my friend Jeff across town, and the thermometer on the front porch read minus 40 degrees. And don't bother asking if that cell phone was ringing. It was ringing, and I thought, OK, I'm going to call Jeff. I'm going to call Jeff. And I called Jeff, and I said, I'm going to call Jeff, and I said, I'm going to call Jeff, and I said, I'm going to call Jeff, and I said, and don't bother asking if that's Celsius or Fahrenheit. Minus 40 is where the two scales meet. It was very cold. And as I stood on the front porch, fumbling in my pockets, I found I didn't have my keys. In fact, I could see them through the window, lying on the dining room table where I had left them. So I quickly ran around and tried all the other doors and windows, and they were locked tight. I thought about calling a locksmith. At least I had my cell phone, but at midnight, it could take a while for a locksmith to show up, and it was cold. I couldn't go back to my friend Jeff's house for the night, because I had an early flight to Europe the next morning, and I needed to get my passport and my suitcase. So, desperate and freezing cold, I found a large rock, and I broke through the basement window, cleared out the shards of glass. I crawled through. I found a piece of cardboard and taped it up over the whole opening, figuring that in the morning, on the way to the airport, I could call my contractor and ask him to fix it. This was going to be expensive, but probably no more expensive than a middle-of-the-night locksmith. So I figured, under the circumstances, I was coming out even. Now, I'm a neuroscientist by training, and I know a little bit about how the brain performs under stress. It releases cortisol, that raises your heart rate, it modulates adrenaline levels and it clouds your thinking. So the next morning, when I woke up, I'm too little asleep, worrying about the hole in the window and the mental note that I had to call my contractor and the freezing temperatures and the meetings I had upcoming in Europe. And with all the cortisol in my brain, my thinking was cloudy, but I didn't know it was cloudy, because my thinking was cloudy. And it wasn't until I got to the airport check-in counter that I realized I didn't have my passport. So I raced home in the snow and ice, 40 minutes, got my passport, raced back to the airport. I made it just in time, but they had given away my seat to someone else, so I got stuck in the back of the plane, next to the bathrooms, in a seat that wouldn't recline, on an eight-hour flight. Well, I had a lot of time to think during those eight hours of no sleep. And I started wondering, are there things that I can do, systems that I can put into place that'll prevent bad things from happening to me? That'll prevent bad things from happening? Or, at least if bad things happen, we'll minimize the likelihood of it being a total catastrophe. So I started thinking about that, but my thoughts didn't crystallize until about a month later. I was having dinner with my colleague Danny Kahneman, the Nobel Prize winner, and I somewhat embarrassedly told him about having broken my window and, you know, forgot my passport. And Danny shared with me that he'd been practicing something called prospective hindsight. It's something that he had gotten from the psychologist Gary Klein, who had written about it a few years before, also called the premortem. Now, you all know what the postmortem is. Whenever there's a disaster, a team of experts come in and they try to figure out what went wrong, right? Well, in the premortem, Danny explained, you look ahead and you try to figure out all the things that could go wrong, and then you try to figure out what you can do to prevent those things from happening or to minimize the damage. So what I want to talk to you about today are some of the things we can do in the form of a premortem. Some of them are obvious, some of them are not so obvious. I'll start with the obvious ones. Around the home, designate a place for things that are easily lost. Now, this sounds like common sense, and it is, but there's a lot of science to back this up based on the way our spatial memory works. There's a structure in the brain called the hippocampus that evolved over tens of thousands of years to keep track of the locations of important things. Where the well is, where fish can be found, that stand of fruit trees, where the friendly and enemy tribes live. The hippocampus is the part of the brain that in London taxicab drivers becomes enlarged. It's the part of the brain that allows squirrels to find their nuts. And if you're wondering, somebody actually did the experiment where they cut off the olfactory sense of the squirrels, and they could still find their nuts. They weren't using smell, they were using the hippocampus, this exquisitely evolved mechanism in the brain for finding things. But it's really good for things that don't move around much, not so good for things that move around. So this is why we lose car keys and reading glasses and passports. So in the home, designate a spot for your keys, a hook by the door, maybe a decorative bowl, for your passport, a particular drawer, for your reading glasses, a particular table. If you designate a spot and you're scrupulous about it, your things will always be there when you look for them. What about travel? Take a cell phone picture of your credit cards, your driver's license, your passport. Mail it to yourself so it's in the cloud. If these things are lost or stolen, you can facilitate replacement. Now, these are some rather obvious things. Remember, when you're under stress, the brain releases cortisol. Cortisol is toxic, and it causes cloudy thinking. So part of the practice of the premortem is to recognize that under stress, you're not going to be at your best, and you should put systems in place. And there's perhaps no more stressful a situation than when you're confronted with a medical decision to make. And at some point, all of us are going to be in that position where we have to make a very important decision about the future of our medical care or that of a loved one, to help them with the decision. And so I want to talk about that, and I'm going to talk about a very particular medical condition. But this stands as a proxy for all kinds of medical decision-making, and indeed for financial decision-making and social decision-making. Any kind of decision you have to make that would benefit from a rational assessment of the facts. So, suppose you go to your doctor and the doctor says, I just got your lab work back. Your cholesterol is a little high. Now, you all know that high cholesterol is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, heart attack, stroke. And so you're thinking having high cholesterol isn't the best thing, and so the doctor says, you know, I'd like to give you a drug that'll help you lower your cholesterol, a statin. And you've probably heard of statins. You know that they're among the most widely prescribed drugs in the world today. And so you're thinking, yeah, give me the statin. But there's a question you should ask at this point, a statistic you should ask for that most doctors don't like talking about and pharmaceutical companies like talking about even less. It's for the number needed to treat. Now, what is this, the NNT? It's the number of people that need to take a drug or undergo a surgery or any medical procedure before one person is helped. And you're thinking, what kind of crazy statistic is that? The number should be one. My doctor wouldn't prescribe something to me if it's not going to help. But actually, medical practice doesn't work that way. And it's not the doctor's fault. If anybody's fault, it's the fault of scientists like me. We haven't figured out the underlying mechanisms well enough. But GlaxoSmithKline estimates that 90 percent of the drugs work in only 30 to 50 percent of the people. So the number needed to treat for the most widely prescribed statin, what do you suppose it is? How many people have to take it before one person's helped? Three hundred. This is according to research by research practitioners Jerome Gruppen and Pamela Hartzband, independently confirmed by Bloomberg.com. I ran through the numbers myself. Three hundred people have to take the drug for a year before one heart attack, stroke or other adverse event is prevented. Now, you're probably thinking, well, OK, one in three hundred chance of lowering my cholesterol. Give me the prescription anyway. But you should ask at this point for another statistic, and that is, tell me about the side effects, right? So for this particular drug, the side effects occur in five percent of the patients. And they include terrible things, debilitating muscle and joint pain, gastrointestinal distress. But now you're thinking, well, five percent, not very likely it's going to happen to me, I'll still take the drug. But wait a minute. Remember, under stress, we're not thinking clearly, and we're going to work through this ahead of time so you don't have to manufacture the chain of reasoning on the spot. Three hundred people take the drug, right? One person's helped. Five percent of those three hundred have side effects. That's 15 people. You're 15 times more likely to be harmed by the drug than you are to be helped by the drug. Now, I'm not saying whether you should take the statin or not. I'm just saying you should have this conversation with your doctor. Medical ethics requires it. It's part of the principle of informed consent. You have the right to have access to this kind of information to begin the conversation about whether you want to take the risks or not. Now, you might be thinking I've pulled this number out of the air for shock value. But in fact, it's rather typical, this number needed to treat. For the most widely performed surgery on men over the age of 50, removal of the prostate for cancer, the number needed to treat is 49. That's right, 49 surgeries are done for every one person who's helped. And the side effects in that case occur in 50 percent of the patients. They include impotence, erectile dysfunction, urinary incontinence, rectal tearing, fecal incontinence. And if you're lucky, and you're one of the 50 percent who has these, they'll only last for a year or two. So the idea of the premortem is to think ahead of time to the questions that you might be able to ask that will push the conversation forward. You don't want to have to manufacture all of this on the spot. And you also want to think about things like quality of life, because you have a choice oftentimes. Do I want a shorter life that's pain-free or a longer life that might have a great deal of pain towards the end? These are things to talk about and think about now with your family and your loved ones. You might change your mind in the heat of the moment, but at least you're practiced with this kind of thinking. Remember, our brain, under stress, releases cortisol. And one of the things that happens at that moment is a whole bunch of systems shut down. There's an evolutionary reason for this. Face to face with a predator, you don't need your digestive system or your libido or your immune system, because if your body is expending metabolism on those things and you don't react quickly, you might become the lion's lunch, and then none of those things matter. Unfortunately, one of the things that goes out the window during those times of stress is rational, logical thinking, as Danny Kahneman and his colleagues have shown. So we need to train ourselves to think ahead to these kinds of situations. I think the important point here is recognizing that all of us are flawed. We all are going to fail now and then. The idea is to think ahead to what those failures might be, to put systems in place that will help minimize the damage or to prevent the bad things from happening in the first place. Getting back to that snowy night in Montreal, when I got back from my trip, I had my contractor install a combination lock next to the door with a key to the front door in it, an easy-to-remember combination. And I have to admit, I still have piles of mail that haven't been sorted and piles of emails that I haven't gone through. So I'm not completely organized, but I see organization as a gradual process, and I'm getting there. Thank you very much. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. THE INTERNET IS page 4 of 14

analysis.summary: In this meeting, the focus was predominantly on stress management, decision making under stress, and the method of 'prospective hindsight' or the 'premortem' to predict and prevent potential issues. The speaker, a trained neuroscientist, shared personal experiences illustrating how stress might affect decision making. The speaker described how cortisol, which the brain releases under stress, can cloud thinking. He emphasized the need for prior planning in order to minimize the impact of potential problems. The speaker delved into topics like spatial memory, neural mechanisms, decision-making during medical emergencies, and medical ethics.
recommendations: Practising the premortem method to improve strategic planning.
Creating systems to minimize damage or prevent problems.
Taking steps to improve organization and reduce stress levels.
Engaging in conversations about potential risks and implications during high-stakes decision-making processes.

transcript: Hello, everyone. Thank you guys for coming to our weekly student success meeting And let's just get started. So I have our list of chronically absent students here, and I've been noticing a troubling trend A lot of students are skipping on Fridays. Does anyone have any idea what's going on? I've heard some of my mentees talking about how it's really hard to get out of bed on Fridays It might be good if we did something like a pancake breakfast to encourage them to come I think that's a great idea. Let's try that next week It might also be because a lot of students have been getting sick now that it's getting colder outside I've had a number of students come by my office with symptoms like sniffling and coughing We should put up posters with tips for not getting sick since it's almost flu season like you know wash your hands after the bathroom Stuff like that. I think that's a good idea, and it'll be a good reminder for the teachers as well So one other thing I wanted to talk about There's a student. I've noticed here John Smith. He's missed seven days already, and it's only November Does anyone have an idea what's going on with him? I might be able to fill in the gaps there I talked to John today, and he's really stressed out He's been dealing with helping his parents take care of his younger siblings during the day It might actually be a good idea if he spoke to the guidance counselor a little bit I can talk to John today if you want to send him to my office after you meet with him It's a lot to deal with for a middle schooler Great, thanks, and and I can help out with the family's child care needs. I'll look for some free or low-cost Resources in the community to share with John and he can share them with his family great well some really good ideas here today Thanks for coming, and if no one has anything else. I think we can wrap up

analysis.summary: The weekly student success meeting was held to discuss the increasing number of chronically absent students. One worrying trend was the high amount of absences every Friday, which may be because students find it challenging waking up or due to increased instances of sickness with the advent of the colder months. A student named John Smith was of particular concern due to him missing seven days already. It was discovered that he had been responsible for taking care of his younger siblings, which had been quite stressful for him.

key_decisions.decision: Initiate a pancake breakfast to encourage student attendance on Fridays.
key_decisions.context: A lot of students are skipping school on Fridays because they find it hard to wake up. A pancake breakfast idea was brought up as a possible motivator for students to attend.
key_decisions.impact: This could potentially improve attendance rates on Fridays and enhance student engagement and overall success.

key_decisions.decision: Put up posters with flu prevention tips.
key_decisions.context: The increase in absences might be due to students falling sick during the colder months. A suggestion was made to put up posters with tips to prevent getting the flu.
key_decisions.impact: A potential decrease in student absences due to sickness and increased awareness of disease prevention among students and teachers.

key_decisions.decision: Provide John Smith with support through the guidance counselor.
key_decisions.context: John Smith's frequent absences, presumably due to the responsibility of looking after his younger siblings during the day. A participant proposed he talk to the guidance counselor for support.
key_decisions.impact: This could help John Smith better manage his responsibilities and improve his school attendance.

action_items.task: Implement a pancake breakfast on Fridays.
Create and put up flu prevention posters around the school.
Talk to John Smith and provide him with necessary guidance.
Look for free or low-cost childcare resources in the community for John's family.

topics_discussed: Struggles of a particular student, John Smith
recommendations: Follow up on the implementation of the pancake breakfasts and the effect it has on Friday attendance.
Check the effectiveness of the flu prevention tips in reducing sickness-related absences.
Monitor John Smith's situation closely and provide further support if needed.
Continue brainstorming additional strategies to boost student attendance and success.

transcript: Thanks for coming to today's monthly meeting. Let's start with apologies for absence. Oh, and before I forget, Frank Lyons is running a bit late. He texted me this morning. And Gary Cope and Carl Madden emailed apologies. Anyone else? Joey Balamwisi can't make it. She's struggling with some personal issues. I think she's got some sort of foot thing that she's got... OK, thank you. Where's Clive? Oh, I completely forgot, yes. He can't be here. He's had to go to a meeting elsewhere. Dammit. Oh, and Janet Bowers is off sick as well. Oh, that's a surprise. To tell you the truth, I forgot what she looked like. And I'm delighted to announce we have a new team member with us and specialist minute-taker. So, for the benefit of the new addition to the team, shall we all introduce ourselves and what we get up to? Yeah? OK, I'll start. Hello, I'm Rita, Managing Director, as you know. Hi, I'm Jason Somerville. I'm the new Project and Programme Manager for Marketing. I just transferred over from the US office. And I just want to say how excited I am about this new role, especially with some of our new products coming on board. And I also wanted to say how sorry I am to hear about the loss of our HR manager, Sarah Bryant. I think that's going to be an incredible loss to the team. Oh, yeah, I'm Lucy Strokes, PA to Rita. I'm Sue Carpenter, with a D, and I'm the Sales Director. And I'm Julian Geddes, the new HR Manager. OK, on to the next item. Are there any matters arising from the previous minutes? No. Fine. Well, next item on the agenda, I'd like Lucy to talk us through her thoughts on this. Yeah, well, there's been an actual problem with car parking, ever since Orchard and Shipman moved into the new offices at the back. And we knew this was going to happen eventually, but, you know, our staff have got used to the extra spaces. And what's happened, there's been a few arguments. There was a really bad one where one of our lot complained to one of their lot, which is really bad because we're trying to, like, it's just started us with a bad reputation. So what we need to do is let our lot know that the spaces belong to them, actually. I'm sorry, are you saying there is a problem with car parking? I didn't quite catch all of what you said. Yeah. Also, a number of the sales team need their car throughout the day, and they want to know what the company proposes to do about this issue. I'm not sure. We need to send an email letting all the staff know there are only five spaces that belong to us. Well, I think we should think about priority parking as well. It's the only way we're going to stop people rowing on a regular basis. Sorry, I got held up in a previous meeting. OK, it's OK. We're just discussing car parking issues. I ride a bike. Yes, I do too. You ride a bike? Yes. Oh, really? And does it have a bell on it? Actually, yes, it does. Please, can we get back? OK, I mentioned priority parking. We need to make a decision on this. I witnessed a fight last week between two members of staff. Oh, stop exaggerating. It was just a heated discussion. I was perfectly in my rights to stand up for myself. Some loser came up to me and said that my car has taken up two parking spaces. Now that's just ridiculous. Well, you do drive a tank and it does take up two spaces. I think priority parking is a good idea, Julian. Thank you. I think that anyone that needs their car for work and uses it during work hours should be given priority at the sales team. What happens if one of them is off sick? Sue, can we just decide on the priority spaces first? Well, I can think of about four people on the sales team that use their cars regularly. I'll get back to you after the meeting, but I'm pretty sure it's four. Well, that should leave enough space for management. Provided, that is, that Jason gives up the tractor. How about two car parking spaces for visitors as well? Respective clients might need their spaces. Completely forgot about that. Actually, yes. Let's make it three. Three. Oh, please, would you both put your phones away? It's very distracting. OK. Right, three spaces. As it's a difficult area to park with a two-hour restriction. And client meetings are always running over. That would leave us with two spaces left to be allocated. Have I got a space? Rita, Rita, client meetings shouldn't be running over two hours. I mean, round of 40 minutes max. Well, I have different types of meeting from you. Yes, but if meetings overrun, I mean, clients just switch off and get bored. Really? Yeah, can we please get back to the agenda item? I do have another meeting to go to after this. The car park is not an issue for me, as I travel by bicycle, as does Frank. Look, I suggest Sue and Jason are allocated the two spaces. Look, I don't mean to be petty, but Jason really does take up two spaces. Excuse me, I would like to say... Listen, if he parks by the garages in the corner where he normally parks, he's normally OK there. So let's have him have that parking space. Listen, forgive me, this is just getting a bit silly. Jason, you need to park by the garages. And I'll coordinate letting the next priority member know if anyone is off sick. OK, great. So can we all agree that we send a list to all staff, advising them about the priority parking? Is that OK? Great. And if no one is listening, I'll send it. Also think that if anybody parks inconsiderately, that they should lose their car parking privilege. Oh. What does everyone think about that? Lucy? What do you think? Yeah, he's right. OK. That settles that. Settles what? Loss of privilege or parking by the garage? Both. All right, so I'll put a sign up with my name on it in my parking space. Oh, can you put a sign up on all the spaces, Jason? Oh, OK. Why don't I get a list and then I'll circulate it so there's no confusion? Fine, Jason. You do it. Sorry, can I just say... OK, OK. Moving on to the next item on the agenda. Staff morale. Sue, can you explain the background to this? Sue has identified a growing problem with staff morale. Can you all refer to the issued report? I wish Clive was here. I mean, actually, he really needs to be here. No, he doesn't. I'm here. Why does he need to be here? Please, carry on. Well, there is a concern in some departments that there is low staff morale. This is indicated by the recent low sales figures and also increased sickness absence in some of the departments. I'm sorry, I don't seem to have the report. Thank you. Right, well, there seems to be a significance problem with staff morale in the sales team and also sickness absence and also company-wide, particularly on Mondays and Fridays. There is definitely low morale in the company in certain departments. New changes have been introduced, like the IT system. People just want to know why certain people have left, why there's been restructuring and whether their jobs are safe. Yeah, isn't this just gossip? Sounds like excuses and laziness to me. Anyway, it clearly is the case that sales figures are at their lowest since February last year. And it's mainly to do with the amount of absences from the sales team. The recent launch of Comet Software has caused problems too because it seems that people haven't had enough training and are therefore making a number of mistakes. I've done my best. It's a big department. I would like to say that the basic instruction handout was given out and everyone was shown step-by-step easy steps about how this should be done. And everyone was provided with a... Well, should have been provided... Well, no, actually they were provided with a password that would allow them to log into the new system. OK, so what has this got to do with staff morale? It's what people are struggling with new software. They're making mistakes, it slows them down, it demotivates them. Anyway, if you could all look at the second report. Lucy and I produced an anonymous questionnaire to get feedback from staff about issues. If you have a look, you'll see very clearly the feedback statistics. And Lucy, I don't mean to pick on you, but you were given a password and like everyone else you seem to have mislaid it or lost it and then you emailed me... What is this losing or forgetting passwords got to do with low morale? And also, everyone puts down poor management when you talk about morale. It's just a waste of time, these questionnaires. Look, there are issues that have been raised. Things like lack of training, lack of effective appraisals. I do appraisals. When was the last time you conducted a staff appraisal? Anyway, the point is that we need to be working a little harder to get people on side and we also found out from the questionnaire that some of the issues are to do with the recent restructuring, the job losses, poor management in some departments and also, as I've mentioned, the lack of training on the new software. Well, thank you for that Sue. You do seem to have taken on a lot recently. Those are our few reasons. What would you say was the predominant reason so that we can begin to tackle one at a time, maybe start work on the major one first? Well, I think it might be a good idea if you and I had a separate meeting about that. Why don't we move on to the second issue now? Well, OK, we can hold on that but maybe we could have one after this meeting. OK. But, you know, Sue, these issues really need to be dealt with now. OK, I take your point but I do wish Clive was here. OK, maybe we could discuss the new appraisal system now. We could have an awards night. Some sort of evening to boost morale. Yeah, yeah, get John Cook Company expense, perfect. Or some sort of team challenge, get everyone pulling together. Maybe in the daytime first. Yeah, what about go-karting? Is that a team challenge? What about party pilates? What? Darts. Guys like darts. Everyone's a winner. That's quite a good idea actually. Yeah, and I like darts. No, I don't like darts. I think we should send a questionnaire rather than management deciding what motivates the team. Darts. No, no, I might kill someone. I'm glad you consider everyone, Jason. OK, so we'll ask the staff, then we'll put it to a vote. Yeah, great idea. So we'll give them some options, put it to a vote and then there'll be no excuse for any complaints. OK, time's ticking on. Can we all have a think? I've got some ideas for the next meeting and then at the meeting we can decide on about six and put it to a company vote, yeah? Why don't we decide on those things now while they're still fresh in everybody's minds? Yeah, and those issues do need addressing now. OK, so what have we got? We have go-karting, awards night, party pilates, darts and drinking evening. We need more than that. Let's all come up with four and email them over in the next two days and I'll take it from there. So, moving on, yes, IT issues. So what are the IT issues? I heard there was a problem on Friday and I was in St Albans with a new client. Friday's issues took me quite a long time to investigate. In fact, it took me pretty much all of my afternoon. The F drive backup recovery disassociated itself somehow from the PCP main framework. I found that this was a problem dating back to the beginning of last month when the PCP was originally reinstalled. Somehow, quite a large component from the logitive rebix hadn't been installed in the reinstallation. Indeed, this was also a problem with the external energy source administration detail being overlooked. Frank, just try explaining that back to us as if we're five-year-olds, would you? Oh, jeez. Shall I continue? There was an external energy issue preventing us from powering up our mainframe and sub-feeders. Do you mean there was a power cut, Frank? Yes, in simple terms. Thank you. So how can we avoid this happening again? I guess it would be a matter for contacting the electricity supplier. Pay the electricity bill? Yes. Can we minute accounts please pay the electricity bills on time? Agreed? Agreed. And maybe we should have sent Frank on an effective communication skills course. Agreed, yeah. Right, moving swiftly on. What about the training issue? Oh, I've been thinking about that and I've got an idea but I want to run it past Clive first. Maybe we could save that for the next meeting? Oh, oh. OK, but I mean I think we should have that meeting sooner rather than later. OK. Maybe in the next two weeks? Well, not everybody needs to be there. I'd like myself and Clive and Frank as it's relevant to them. But I think that I should be there as well. That's my final decision, Sue, thank you. I'll speak with Clive and let you know date, Frank. Moving on, yes, Gary couldn't attend today so he's provided us with a financial report which in summary, well, we've had a tough year. The balance sheet's about even and we're doing pretty well in contract sales so thanks very much for that. On the downside, loss of revenue in handset sales abroad. How much are we down on last year? I mean Gary's layout here is quite confusing. This figure here, 52 or 21? I mean, I'm not familiar with this kind of financial report. He seems to have changed it. That's a big difference. Let me just have a look. I've got a bit of accounting experience. Thanks, Julian. You know, that's a lot. Seriously, I mean, what could be causing it? It's actually neither of those numbers, it's 11. Are we in red or black? Well, I think if we can't pay our utility bill, I think we're in the red. Actually, we are in the black but we're down on last year. OK, well, thank you for that. I think that's about all for this meeting. Just leave us with any other business. Yeah, the people are leaving plates and aren't washing up their plates in the kitchen. But it is, it's an issue. It stinks. On the same note, actually, the shower room recently. Have you seen the state of the shower room? Yeah. OK, can I just say... I've never been in there. Yes, you should because you ride your bike. OK, we've got a general cleanliness problem. And as far as those issues are concerned, you must make sure they're scheduled for the next meeting. All right, everyone happy? Is the dishwasher not working?

analysis.summary: The meeting involved a discussion on several key issues facing the company: parking issues, low staff morale, IT issues, and financial performance. The team agreed on a priority parking system. Low morale was tied to recent staff changes, lacking training, and software issues. The team agreed to come up with a list of ideas for a team event to boost morale. Faced with IT issues relating to a power outage and staff struggles with new software, a meeting was scheduled to further discuss training solutions. Discussed financial report indicated losses in international handset sales though the company is overall in the black.

key_decisions.decision: Allocation of car park spaces based on priority.
key_decisions.context: There have been disputes among staff regarding parking, leading to a proposal for a priority parking system. The decision was made to allocate parking spaces based on work requirement, positional role, and visitors.
key_decisions.impact: The decision is hoped to reduce conflict and boost morale among staff, contributing to a better work environment.

key_decisions.context: Staff morale is reported lower due to a myriad of reasons. A decision was made to organize a team event to boost morale.
key_decisions.impact: Boosting team morale could lead to enhanced productivity and reduced staff turnover.

key_decisions.context: The company is facing IT issues with the new software and power backups, and many staff struggle to use the new system.
key_decisions.impact: Effective use of IT can improve overall performance and productivity.

action_items.task: Compile a list of ideas for team building events.
Arrange a meeting to discuss training solutions for IT.
Prepare signs for the allocated parking spaces.
Pay the electricity bill on time

participants: Jason Somerville (New Project and Programme Manager for Marketing)
recommendations: The meetings should be more efficiently managed to control diversions and stay relevant to the agenda.
Improve meeting preparation by ensuring all participants receive and understand pre-meeting documents.
Meetings should be more focussed on solutions and actionable steps.
Improvements for IT situation should be made immediately due to its impact on staff morale and overall productivity.
Investigate more deeply into the root causes of low staff morale and formulate a detailed response strategy.

title: Meeting - Effective Meetings_ Simulated Exercise for Chairing & Minute Taking.mp3
transcript: Thanks for coming to today's monthly meeting. Let's start with apologies for absence. Oh, and before I forget, Frank Lyons is running a bit late. He texted me this morning. And Gary Cope and Carl Madden emailed apologies. Anyone else? Joey Balamwisi can't make it. She's struggling with some personal issues. I think she's got some sort of foot thing that she's got... OK, thank you. Where's Clive? Oh, I completely forgot, yes. He can't be here. He's had to go to a meeting elsewhere. Dammit. Oh, and Janet Bowers is off sick as well. Oh, that's a surprise. To tell you the truth, I forgot what she looked like. And I'm delighted to announce we have a new team member with us and specialist minute-taker. So, for the benefit of the new addition to the team, shall we all introduce ourselves and what we get up to? Yeah? OK, I'll start. Hello, I'm Rita, Managing Director, as you know. Hi, I'm Jason Somerville. I'm the new Project and Programme Manager for Marketing. I just transferred over from the US office. And I just want to say how excited I am about this new role, especially with some of our new products coming on board. And I also wanted to say how sorry I am to hear about the loss of our HR manager, Sarah Bryant. I think that's going to be an incredible loss to the team. Oh, yeah, I'm Lucy Strokes, PA to Rita. I'm Sue Carpenter, with a D, and I'm the Sales Director. And I'm Julian Geddes, the new HR Manager. OK, on to the next item. Are there any matters arising from the previous minutes? No. Fine. Well, next item on the agenda, I'd like Lucy to talk us through her thoughts on this. Yeah, well, there's been an actual problem with car parking, ever since Orchard and Shipman moved into the new offices at the back. And we knew this was going to happen eventually, but, you know, our staff have got used to the extra spaces. And what's happened, there's been a few arguments. There was a really bad one where one of our lot complained to one of their lot, which is really bad because we're trying to, like, it's just started us with a bad reputation. So what we need to do is let our lot know that the spaces belong to them, actually. I'm sorry, are you saying there is a problem with car parking? I didn't quite catch all of what you said. Yeah. Also, a number of the sales team need their car throughout the day, and they want to know what the company proposes to do about this issue. I'm not sure. We need to send an email letting all the staff know there are only five spaces that belong to us. Well, I think we should think about priority parking as well. It's the only way we're going to stop people rowing on a regular basis. Sorry, I got held up in a previous meeting. OK, it's OK. We're just discussing car parking issues. I ride a bike. Yes, I do too. You ride a bike? Yes. Oh, really? And does it have a bell on it? Actually, yes, it does. Please, can we get back? OK, I mentioned priority parking. We need to make a decision on this. I witnessed a fight last week between two members of staff. Oh, stop exaggerating. It was just a heated discussion. I was perfectly in my rights to stand up for myself. Some loser came up to me and said that my car has taken up two parking spaces. Now that's just ridiculous. Well, you do drive a tank and it does take up two spaces. I think priority parking is a good idea, Julian. Thank you. I think that anyone that needs their car for work and uses it during work hours should be given priority at the sales team. What happens if one of them is off sick? Sue, can we just decide on the priority spaces first? Well, I can think of about four people on the sales team that use their cars regularly. I'll get back to you after the meeting, but I'm pretty sure it's four. Well, that should leave enough space for management. Provided, that is, that Jason gives up the tractor. How about two car parking spaces for visitors as well? Respective clients might need their spaces. Completely forgot about that. Actually, yes. Let's make it three. Three. Oh, please, would you both put your phones away? It's very distracting. OK. Right, three spaces. As it's a difficult area to park with a two-hour restriction. And client meetings are always running over. That would leave us with two spaces left to be allocated. Have I got a space? Rita, Rita, client meetings shouldn't be running over two hours. I mean, round of 40 minutes max. Well, I have different types of meeting from you. Yes, but if meetings overrun, I mean, clients just switch off and get bored. Really? Yeah, can we please get back to the agenda item? I do have another meeting to go to after this. The car park is not an issue for me, as I travel by bicycle, as does Frank. Look, I suggest Sue and Jason are allocated the two spaces. Look, I don't mean to be petty, but Jason really does take up two spaces. Excuse me, I would like to say... Listen, if he parks by the garages in the corner where he normally parks, he's normally OK there. So let's have him have that parking space. Listen, forgive me, this is just getting a bit silly. Jason, you need to park by the garages. And I'll coordinate letting the next priority member know if anyone is off sick. OK, great. So can we all agree that we send a list to all staff, advising them about the priority parking? Is that OK? Great. And if no one is listening, I'll send it. Also think that if anybody parks inconsiderately, that they should lose their car parking privilege. Oh. What does everyone think about that? Lucy? What do you think? Yeah, he's right. OK. That settles that. Settles what? Loss of privilege or parking by the garage? Both. All right, so I'll put a sign up with my name on it in my parking space. Oh, can you put a sign up on all the spaces, Jason? Oh, OK. Why don't I get a list and then I'll circulate it so there's no confusion? Fine, Jason. You do it. Sorry, can I just say... OK, OK. Moving on to the next item on the agenda. Staff morale. Sue, can you explain the background to this? Sue has identified a growing problem with staff morale. Can you all refer to the issued report? I wish Clive was here. I mean, actually, he really needs to be here. No, he doesn't. I'm here. Why does he need to be here? Please, carry on. Well, there is a concern in some departments that there is low staff morale. This is indicated by the recent low sales figures and also increased sickness absence in some of the departments. I'm sorry, I don't seem to have the report. Thank you. Right, well, there seems to be a significance problem with staff morale in the sales team and also sickness absence and also company-wide, particularly on Mondays and Fridays. There is definitely low morale in the company in certain departments. New changes have been introduced like the IT system. People just want to know why certain people have left, why there's been restructuring and whether their jobs are safe. Yeah, isn't this just gossip? Sounds like excuses and laziness to me. Anyway, it clearly is the case that sales figures are at their lowest since February last year. And it's mainly to do with the amount of absences from the sales team. The recent launch of Comet Software has caused problems too because it seems that people haven't had enough training and are therefore making a number of mistakes. I've done my best. It's a big department. I would like to say that the basic instruction handout was given out and everyone was shown step-by-step easy steps about how this should be done. And everyone was provided with, well, should have been provided, well, no, actually they were provided with a password that would allow them to log into the new system. Okay, so what has this got to do with staff morale? It's what people struggling with new software, you know, they're making mistakes, it slows them down, it demotivates them. Anyway, if you could all look at the second report, Lucy and I produced an anonymous questionnaire to get feedback from staff about issues. If you have a look, you'll see very clearly the feedback statistics. And Lucy, I don't mean to pick on you, but you were given a password and like everyone else, you seem to have mislaid it or lost it and then you emailed me. What is this losing or forgetting passwords got to do with low morale? And also, everyone puts down poor management when you talk about morale. It's just a waste of time, these questionnaires. Look, there are issues that have been raised, things like lack of training, you know, lack of effective appraisals. I do appraisals. Well, when was the last time you conducted a staff appraisal? Anyway, the point is that we need to be working a little harder to get people on side and we also found out from the questionnaire that some of the issues are to do with the recent restructuring, the job losses, poor management in some departments and also, as I've mentioned, the lack of training on the new software. Well, thank you for that Sue. You do seem to have taken on a lot recently. Look, as there are a few reasons, what would you say was the predominant reason so that we can begin to tackle one at a time, maybe start work on the major one first? Well, I think it might be a good idea if you and I had a separate meeting about that. Why don't we move on to the second issue now? Well, OK, we can hold on that, but maybe we could have one after this meeting. OK. But, you know, Sue, these issues really need to be dealt with now. OK, I take your point, but I do wish Clive was here. OK, maybe we could discuss the new appraisal system now. We could have an awards night. Some sort of evening to boost morale. Yeah, yeah, get John Cook Company expense, perfect. Or some sort of team challenge, get everyone pulling together. Maybe in the daytime first. Yeah, what about go-karting? Is that a team challenge? What about party pilates? What? Darts. Guys like darts. Everyone's a winner. That's quite a good idea, actually. Yeah, and I like darts. No, I don't like darts. I think we should send a questionnaire rather than management deciding what motivates the team. Darts. No, no, I might kill someone. I'm glad you consider everyone, Jason. OK, so we'll ask the staff, then we'll put it to a vote. Yeah, great idea. So we'll give them some options, put it to a vote, and then there'll be no excuse for any complaints. OK, time's ticking on. Can we all have a think? I've got some ideas for the next meeting, and then at the meeting we can decide on about six and put it to a company vote, yeah? Why don't we decide on those things now while they're still fresh in everybody's minds? Yeah, and those issues do need addressing now. OK, so what have we got? We have go-karting, awards night, party pilates, darts and drinking evening. We need more than that. Let's all come up with four and email them over in the next two days and I'll take it from there. Moving on, yes, IT issues. So what are the IT issues? I heard there was a problem on Friday and I was in St Albans with a new client. Friday's issues took me quite a long time to investigate. In fact, it took me pretty much all of my afternoon. The F drive backup recovery disassociated itself somehow from the PCP main framework. I found that this was a problem dating back to the beginning of last month when the PCP was originally reinstalled. Quite a large component from the logitive rebix hadn't been installed in the reinstallation. Indeed, this was also a problem with the external energy source administration detail being overlooked. Frank, just try explaining that back to us as if we're five-year-olds, would you? Oh, jeez. Shall I continue? There was an external energy issue preventing us from powering up our mainframe and sub-feeders. Do you mean there was a power cut, Frank? Yes, in simple terms. Thank you. So how can we avoid this happening again? I guess it would be a matter for contacting the electricity supplier. Pay the electricity bill? Yes. Can we minute accounts please pay the electricity bills on time? Agreed? Agreed. And maybe we should have sent Frank on an effective communication skills course. Agreed, yeah. Right, moving swiftly on. Is there a training issue? Oh, I've been thinking about that and I've got an idea but I want to run it past Clive first. Maybe we could save that for the next meeting? Oh. OK, but I mean I think we should have that meeting sooner rather than later. OK. In the next two weeks? Not everybody needs to be there. I'd like myself and Clive and Frank as it's relevant to them. But I think that I should be there as well. That's my final decision, Sue. Thank you. I'll speak with Clive and let you know a date, Frank. Moving on, yes, Gary couldn't attend today so he's provided us with a financial report which in summary, well we've had a tough year. The balance sheet's about even and we're doing pretty well in contract sales so thanks very much for that. On the downside, loss of revenue in handset sales abroad. How much are we down on last year? This layout here is quite confusing. This figure here, 52 or 21? I mean, I'm not familiar with this kind of financial report. He seems to have changed it. That's a big difference. Let me just have a look. I've got a bit of accounting experience. Thanks, Julian. You know, that's a lot. Seriously, I mean, what could be causing it? It's actually neither of those numbers. It's 11. Are we in red or black? Well, I think if we can't pay our utility bill, I think we're in the red. Actually, we are in the black, but we're down on last year. Okay, well thank you for that. I think that's about all for this meeting. Just leaves us with any other business. Yeah, the people are leaving plates and aren't washing up their plates in the kitchen. But it is, it's an issue. It stinks. On the same note, actually, the shower room, recently? Have you seen the state of the shower room? Yeah, okay, can I just say? I've never been in there. Yes, you should, because you ride your bike. Okay, we've got a general cleanliness problem. And as far as those issues are concerned, you must make sure they're scheduled for the next meeting. All right, everyone happy? Is the dishwasher not working?

analysis.summary: The meeting began with a number of apologies for absence from team members including Frank Lyons, Gary Cope, Carl Madden, Joey Balamwisi, Clive and Janet Bowers. There was also an introduction of the new members. The main issue discussed during the meeting was concerning car parking. Due to Orchard and Shipman moving into the new offices, the company's staff are now short in spaces. Lucy proposed informing everyone of the five parking spaces that belong to the company and considering priority parking to avoid disputes. A decision was made on priority spaces for sales people who regularly use their cars, company management, and two spaces were reserved for visitors and clients. Sue Carpenter was assigned to identify and confer the sales people who are entitled to priority spaces.

key_decisions.decision: Introduction of priority parking and two spaces reserved for visitors
key_decisions.context: To ease parking dispute issues caused by insufficient parking spaces.
key_decisions.impact: This decision will reserve parking for those who need it the most, to avoid disputes, promote peace and maintain the company's reputation.

action_items.task: Identify employees in sales team who use their cars regularly for work

recommendations: Efficiency should be improved. Less time should be spent on team introductions and digressions, and more focus should be on the main topics for discussion.
Detailing the specific priority parking plan.

title: Meeting - The Expert_ Progress Meeting (Short Comedy Sketch).mp3
transcript: So, I'm happy to report we have succeeded in re-routing our flagships. Way ahead of schedule, yet again. This has allowed us to improve our USPs by 90%. That's nine out of every ten. Excellent, thank you Samuel. Timothy, what's the status with the Linear Solutions? Could you give us the latest on the Square project? The Linear Solutions department has, yet again, functioned at full capacity and we have fulfilled 114% of this month's objectives. You can read the handouts for a detailed account, but in short, as I reported last week, we've decided to use the right angle for the Square project. Now, there's still some debate as to how big a right angle is, so we're testing currently at 90, 97, 100 and 101 degrees. As agreed, I've ensured Anderson cross-checks the design, removing any left angles and doesn't use them in future. Overall, we have very good progress with the design. Are we on track with the schedule? When are we required to start delivering? I'm happy to report that we are ready to start first deliveries tomorrow, which is way ahead of the requested delivery schedule. We've only just finished system testing the prototype and are only halfway through performance testing. We haven't even released an alpha version yet. As I said earlier, we've had very good progress with the design. Yes, we've had very good progress, but I'd say the design of the product is only 75% complete. Well, exactly. That's three out of every four. So we're ready to start shipping tomorrow. What? It doesn't work like that. We'll produce, say, four units, but only ship the first three. Then when you're finally 100% complete with the design, we can then ship the fourth. Excellent work, Timothy. You can proceed with the production. Anderson, send me, please, a revised delivery schedule so I can share it with the client. Well, thank you, everyone. This was very productive. Yet again. Ssssh. Ssssh. Oh. Oh.

analysis.summary: The recent meeting had significant discussions about the company's flagships re-routing and the progress of the Square project by the Linear Solutions department. The team has managed to improve its Unique Selling Propositions (USPs) by 90% due to the early completion of the flagship re-routing. Regarding the Square project, decisions have been made to use right angles, and testing is underway. It was confirmed that Anderson would cross-check the design, eliminating any left angles. Although there is still progress to be made with the design, the team is set to start deliveries earlier than required. Also, a revised delivery schedule would be prepared.

key_decisions.decision: The use of right angles in the Square project
key_decisions.context: The Square project by the Linear Solutions department has chosen to use right angles, and testing at different degrees is ongoing.
key_decisions.impact: A potentially more effective design for the Square project.

key_decisions.decision: Anderson to cross-check and remove left angles in the design
key_decisions.context: To ensure the effectiveness of the right angle approach in the Square project, Anderson was tasked with checking the design for any left angles and ensuring they aren't repeated in the future.
key_decisions.impact: This should improve design accuracy and effectiveness of the Square project.

key_decisions.decision: Starting deliveries ahead of the scheduled timeline
key_decisions.context: While the design of the product has made significant progress, it's not yet complete. However, the decision was made to start delivering the initial units before the completion of the design.
key_decisions.impact: This could enhance customer satisfaction with early delivery but may risk quality if the design is not fully finalized.

action_items.task: Anderson to cross-check the design and remove any left angles
Anderson to prepare a revised delivery schedule

recommendations: Provide a clear deadline for Anderson to cross-check the design and remove any left angles in the future.
Ensure the readiness and testing of the product before starting the delivery of the units.
Ensure that designs are finalized before shifting to production and delivery phase.
